author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Marcia Freedman, First American Woman in Knesset, Dies at 83
description: As a radical gay feminist in historically patriarchal Israel, Ms. Freedman was under constant criticism and was often dismissed by her colleagues.
content: Marcia Freedman, who was the first American-born woman to serve in the Israeli Parliament, known as the Knesset, and who helped lead the feminist movement in Israel in the 1970s, died on Sept. 21 at her home in South Berkeley, Calif. She was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: Mohib Ullah, 46, Dies; Documented Ethnic Cleansing of Rohingya
description: Shot dead by gunmen, he had compiled a list of those who perished in the hope that the data could be used as evidence in international courts.
content: Mohib Ullah, a Rohingya community leader who believed in the power of data to confront the brutality of ethnic cleansing, died on Wednesday, shot by gunmen in a bamboo and tarp shelter in Kutupalong, Bangladesh, the world’s biggest refugee camp. He was 46.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Hawgood
title: A Fresh Perspective on Downtown Youth Culture
description: Marie Tomanova spent the pandemic working on a new photo book, “New York New York.”
content: Name: Marie Tomanova
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz and Maria Cramer
title: How Students Fought a Book Ban and Won, for Now
description: Hundreds of students, parents and residents in York County, Pa., protested limits on books told from the perspective of gay, Black and Latino children.
content: Edha Gupta and Christina Ellis, two high school seniors in York County, Pa., were furious when they read last month in a local paper that their teachers had been effectively banned from using hundreds of books, documentary films and articles in their classrooms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman
title: Canadian Man Who Narrated ISIS Videos Flown to U.S. To Face Terrorism Charge
description: The man, Mohammed Khalifa, was captured in Syria in early 2019. He was part of the Islamic State’s Ministry of Media, which was responsible for publicizing the beheading of the American journalist James Foley.
content: WASHINGTON — A Canadian man who narrated two infamous propaganda videos that the Islamic State used to recruit Westerners and to encourage terrorism attacks was secretly whisked to the United States to face federal prosecution in Virginia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Pat Robertson Ends His Long Run as Host of ‘The 700 Club’
description: Mr. Robertson, the evangelical leader who started the show in the 1960s to help save the Christian Broadcasting Network, said his son would take over as host of the program.
content: The evangelical leader Pat Robertson said on Friday that he was stepping down as host of the “The 700 Club” after more than 50 years at the helm of a program that channeled Christian conservatism into millions of American homes and turned him into a household name.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kessler
title: Balancing Honesty and Optimism in Silicon Valley
description: Is there an ethical way to “fake it til you make it”?
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Is Letitia James Running for Governor? Her Decision Is Coming Soon.
description: Ms. James, New York’s attorney general, has embarked on a campaign-like tour of the state and is discussing her plans with donors and officials.
content: In recent days, Letitia James, New York’s attorney general, has given every public indication that she is thinking about running for governor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shaila Dewan
title: Subduing Suspects Face Down Isn’t Fatal, Research Has Said. Now the Research Is on Trial.
description: For years, the leading experts have testified that prone restraint by police is safe. So why do people keep dying?
content: GREENSBORO, Md. — It was a warm Saturday evening when Jennell Black heard a commotion outside her mobile home on Maryland’s Eastern Shore. Outside her door, four men were holding her 19-year-old son face down, pinning his shoulder, legs and arms. One of them, who turned out to be an off-duty police chief from a nearby town, was lying on top of him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi and Noam Scheiber
title: Inside United Airlines’ Decision to Mandate Coronavirus Vaccines
description: Over the course of a year, the company and its unions grappled with when and how to require vaccination for its 67,000 U.S. employees.
content: Scott Kirby, the chief executive of United Airlines, reached a breaking point while vacationing in Croatia this summer: After receiving word that a 57-year-old United pilot had died after contracting the coronavirus, he felt it was time to require all employees to get vaccinated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Biden Signs Bill Ending Furlough of 3,700 Transportation Workers
description: The measure, which extends expiring transportation programs for a month, had originally been part of a $1 trillion infrastructure bill that stalled in the House this week.
content: WASHINGTON — The Senate met briefly on Saturday to send a bill to President Biden reviving key transportation programs that had lapsed two days earlier and bringing back nearly 4,000 furloughed workers. Hours later, Mr. Biden signed it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Body Believed to Be Miya Marcano’s Is Found, Sheriff Says
description: Ms. Marcano, a 19-year-old college student in Orlando, Fla., was last seen on Sept. 24.
content: A body believed to be Miya Marcano, a 19-year-old college student who was reported missing last month, was found in Orlando, Fla., on Saturday, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac
title: Whistle-Blower to Accuse Facebook of Contributing to Jan. 6 Riot, Memo Says
description: In an internal memo, Facebook defended itself and said that social media was not a primary cause of polarization.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook, which has been under fire from a former employee who has revealed that the social network knew of many of the harms it was causing, was bracing for new accusations over the weekend from the whistle-blower and said in a memo that it was preparing to mount a vigorous defense.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Violent Crime Spikes Among Arabs in Israel as Officials Admit Neglect
description: Killings of Arabs by Arabs have soared in Israel. The prevailing assumption, an official said, was “as long as they are killing each other, that’s their problem.”
content: TAIBEH, Israel — After a day of work in construction, Alaa Sarsour, 25, showered, dressed and walked the short distance to his friend’s pre-wedding henna party in a cobbled alley festooned with ribbons in the old heart of Taibeh, an Arab town in central Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Herrman
title: Will TikTok Make You Buy It?
description: Give any social media platform long enough, and it turns into a mall.
content: In three short years, TikTok has grown in the public imagination from an app for dancing teens into an all-purpose cultural powerhouse, driving trends in music, food, news and politics, and changing the way people communicate online. In the process, it’s also become something else: a place where people buy things. Lots of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Sinema Stars in Her Own Film
description: The Garbo of the Senate leaves Democrats confused and angry.
content: WASHINGTON — Just like the original Sphinx, the Phoenix Sphinx is blocking the way until those who would move ahead solve her riddle:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer and Campbell Robertson
title: Supporters of Abortion Rights, at Nationwide Marches, Try to Regain Momentum
description: A nationwide march for abortion rights on Saturday offered an early test of Democratic enthusiasm in the post-Trump era.
content: Last fall, Hannah Dasgupta spent her days focused on politics, channeling her fear and anger over President Donald J. Trump into activism. Worried about the future of abortion rights, among other issues, during the Trump administration, she joined a group of suburban Ohio women who were working to elect Democrats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: Tallying the Cost of Growing Older
description: Researchers have been studying how much care American adults will require as they age, and for how long.
content: Say you’re a 65-year-old looking ahead, wondering about your health and your finances, pondering what life might be like in 20 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naomi Oreskes and Sofia Andrade
title: Harvard and Other Schools Make a Choice on Fossil Fuels
description: Climate activists on campuses across the country have spent years organizing in the name of fossil fuel divestment. That organizing is starting to pay off.
content: This month, the University of Minnesota, Boston University and Harvard, our own institution, announced that they’ll divest from the fossil fuel industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Ate the Last Cookie, Say
description: Don’t fight the urge to solve this Wendy L. Brandes construction.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is the second Times puzzle from Wendy L. Brandes, and her first solo effort; she made her debut last December in collaboration with Erik Agard, who has a supporting credit in today’s Constructor Notes. This grid is a glide, compared with some of the very rocky roads we’ve traversed on recent Saturdays, but its smoothness incorporates lovely puns and trivia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: An Erotica Pioneer Goes From Hero to Villain for Dozens of Authors
description: In the constantly evolving romance landscape, Blushing Books has long occupied a specific niche: spanking erotica. Now some of its most successful writers just want their books back.
content: Anne Wills was a mother of four who doted on her children, was an active volunteer with a youth swim team, loved animals and was known to those around her as a generous, nurturing, motherly figure in her small town in rural Virginia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Does My Co-op Really Need to Know Everything About My Pet?
description: Co-ops generally have the right to set rules about companion pets, but sometimes the information the board wants seems a little invasive.
content: Q: My co-op recently instituted a pet registration policy. Owners are now being asked to provide details about their pets including distinguishing features, vaccination history, and contact information for veterinarians and pet sitters. I understand that management needs to know who owns a pet, but this level of inquiry feels invasive and unnecessary. I have a cat that never leaves the apartment. Am I obligated to provide all this granular detail?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Emily Cochrane
title: Biden Pulls Back on Infrastructure Bill, Tying It to Social Policy Measure
description: After pressing toward a vote, Democratic leaders accepted “reality” that the bill could not pass before a broad climate change and safety net measure comes together.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden, facing an intraparty battle over his domestic agenda, put his own $1 trillion infrastructure bill on hold on Friday, telling Democrats that a vote on the popular measure must wait until Democrats pass his far more ambitious social policy and climate change package.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Jan. 6 Was Worse Than We Knew
description: The Electoral Count Act needs to be fixed.
content: However horrifying the Jan. 6 riot at the U.S. Capitol appeared in the moment, we know now that it was far worse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aina J. Khan
title: U.K. Aims to Ease Trucker Shortage With Visas Into 2022
description: The decision extended an earlier move to offer three-month visas to foreign drivers, and came as the government also called on military drivers to help resolve a fuel distribution crisis.
content: LONDON — Britain’s government, under increasing pressure to ease a truck driver shortage and supply-chain issues that have left many supermarket shelves depleted and gas pumps dry, said on Saturday that it was extending the temporary visas being offered to thousands of foreign truck drivers into next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Pearl Tytell, Examiner of Dubious Documents, Dies at 104
description: For a half-century, she used her knowledge of handwriting, typewriters, paper and ink to investigate the veracity of checks, letters, contracts and other paperwork.
content: Pearl Tytell, the matriarch of a family of questioned-document examiners whose intricate knowledge of paper, ink, handwriting and typewriters made her a prominent investigator of frauds, forgeries, tax evasion and poison-pen letters, died on Sept. 26 at her home in the Riverdale neighborhood of the Bronx. She was 104.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz, Natalie Kitroeff, Sofía Villamil and Federico Rios
title: Perilous, Roadless Jungle Becomes a Path of Desperate Hope
description: The recent surge at the Mexican border is likely to grow as more migrants, mostly Haitian, risk everything negotiating the notorious Darién Gap on their way to the United States.
content: NECOCLÍ, Colombia — For decades, the Darién Gap, a roadless, lawless stretch of jungle linking South America to the north, was considered so dangerous that only a few thousand people a year were daring, or desperate, enough to try to cross it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Smith
title: Richard H. Kirk, Post-Punk Pioneer of Industrial Music, Dies at 65
description: Cabaret Voltaire, of which he was a founder, began as a band of experimental provocateurs and later moved to the dance floor.
content: Richard H. Kirk, a founding member of the English group Cabaret Voltaire and a major figure in the creation of the post-punk style known as industrial music, has died. He was 65.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Coaston
title: When the Rich Rail Against the ‘Elites’
description: Coastal elites may have power. But so do the wealthy — all over America.
content: I’ve been thinking a lot about wealth and elitism, or more accurately, the concept of who is an “elite” and who isn’t. And I have come to the conclusion that the way we discuss being an “elite” is inaccurate at best, and downright wrong at worst.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo and Emma Bubola
title: Romans Choose From a Crowded Field to Run a Chaotic City
description: Rome has defied efforts to make basic services work, and the incumbent mayor lags in the polls, with no shortage of rivals hoping to take her place.
content: ROME — In the five years since Virginia Raggi became mayor, Rome has had some problems. Garbage has piled up on sidewalks, attracting swarms of sea gulls and crows. A pothole epidemic has riddled city streets. Public buses, already unreliable, have started combusting. And the city’s Christmas tree has looked so sad that Romans nicknamed it “Mangy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Stanley Tucci’s Passion Was Acting. Now, It’s Food.
description: The actor’s new memoir “Taste” explains how a bout with cancer took his passion for ragù and risotto, but also Cuban-Chinese stews and minke whale, to new heights.
content: LONDON — About three years ago, the actor Stanley Tucci was strapped to a board in a New York hospital, while he received radiation therapy to get rid of a tumor at the base of his tongue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Georgia Rolls, Building Its Playoff Hopes and Ending the Razorbacks’
description: A top-10 matchup between the hedges in Athens looked like anything but.
content: ATHENS, Ga. — In a sport rife with traditions and grandstanding and some outright fantasies, some seemingly gospel truths remain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Betsy Joles
title: Saving a Vibrant History, One Frame at a Time
description: Shahid Zaidi is working to preserve the photos his father shot of Pakistan’s first leaders and of its people in the era of the country’s founding.
content: LAHORE, Pakistan — Before Shahid Zaidi was born, before his home was an independent country, his father opened a portrait studio and captured the nation’s emerging history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Texas Man Killed and Dismembered 3 at Motel, Police Say
description: Jason Alan Thornburg, 41, an electrician’s apprentice, told detectives that he “believed that he was being called to commit sacrifices,” according to an arrest warrant.
content: For about two months, the man who stayed in Room 113 at the Mid City Inn in Euless, Texas, would sit outside, reading the Bible and encouraging others to come to church with him, according to a manager of the motel, Kanti Gandhi.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: When Is a ‘Majority’ Not Actually a Majority?
description: The problem of the "constitutional majority" in American politics.
content: The problem in the American system for the principle of “one person, one vote” is that our institutions are not actually set up for political equality among citizens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt and Maggie Haberman
title: The Lawyer Behind the Memo on How Trump Could Stay in Office
description: John Eastman was a little-known but respected conservative lawyer. Then he became influential with Donald Trump — and counseled him on how to retain power after losing the election.
content: John Eastman’s path from little-known academic to one of the most influential voices in Donald J. Trump’s ear in the final days of his presidency began in mid-2019 on Mr. Trump’s favorite platform: television.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: As Bikers Throng the Streets, ‘It’s Like Paris Is in Anarchy’
description: An ecologically minded experiment to make Paris a cycling capital of Europe has led to a million people now pedaling daily — and to rising tensions with pedestrians.
content: PARIS — On a recent afternoon, the Rue de Rivoli looked like this: Cyclists blowing through red lights in two directions. Delivery bike riders fixating on their cellphones. Electric scooters careening across lanes. Jaywalkers and nervous pedestrians scrambling as if in a video game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivy Manners
title: D.I.Y. Hairstyles for Brides
description: From an elegant braided bun to soft beach waves, here are eight chic wedding-day looks you can create on your own.
content: Many brides are choosing to style their own hair these days, whether to avoid the fuss of sitting through hair trials at the salon or because they’re planning a low-key celebration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: They Want to Hand Your Kid a Debit Card. What Do You Do?
description: Start-ups large and small are offering child-friendly debit cards that allow parents to set up guardrails. Picking one depends on your priorities.
content: Introducing your child to the real-world use of money often means hacking together half-baked solutions: jars stuffed with bills combined with repeated trips to the A.T.M. and teenage misuse of the parental credit card.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Battered Towns in England’s North Test Johnson’s Plan to ‘Level Up’
description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson has made far-reaching promises to spread the good life beyond prosperous southeastern England to neglected parts in the middle and North of the country.
content: REDCAR, England — Standing 180 feet tall, the coal bunker that dominated the skyline at the defunct steelworks in northeast England was weathered, discolored and an eyesore to some who lived nearby. Yet it was such a symbol of the region’s industrial heritage that campaigners fought hard to stop its demolition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: What to Know About the 2021 Nobel Prizes
description: The Nobel Prizes will be announced beginning Monday.
content: Nobel Prize season is upon us once again. Every October, committees in Sweden and Norway name laureates in a variety of prizes in the sciences, literature and economics, as well as peace work. In total, six prizes will be awarded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
description: Joshua Kosman and Henri Picciotto, two professionals, knock a cryptic puzzle out of the park.
content: CRYPTIC CROSSWORD — This has been a great year for variety puzzles, in my opinion, with some great new entries to the genre and some excellent guest appearances. Today, we have a cryptic puzzle constructed by Joshua Kosman and Henri Picciotto, the creators of a weekly online subscription puzzle called “Out of Left Field,” as well as the authors of “Word Salad,” a guide to cryptic puzzles that looks stuffed with interesting information.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Biden Tells Democrats Infrastructure Hinges on a Social Policy Bill
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, October 2, 2021.
content: “It doesn’t matter whether it’s in six minutes, six days or six weeks. We’re going to get it done.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin and Jonathan Weisman
title: Biden Throws In With Left, Leaving His Agenda in Doubt
description: Progressives flexed, but remain empty-handed. Moderates feel betrayed. The outcome of their battle could determine Democrats’ fate in the midterms and the success of the Biden presidency.
content: WASHINGTON — For well over a year now, President Biden’s vaunted negotiating style largely boiled down to this: I’m with you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Snoozefest
description: Trenton Charlson’s attention-grabbing Sunday puzzle is anything but.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Today’s print introduction mentions that Trenton Charlson is 25, which makes me doubt time, frankly, because it feels as if we have been solving his Scrabbly grids forever. (It’s actually been less than five years, but he’s prolific — 32 puzzles and counting.) Will Shortz makes note of the modern tools of crossword construction, software and programs that help create thrilling word lists like the one here, but that’s really just part of the equation. Mr. Charlson says, “I value the sort of ‘X-factor’ that makes a puzzle feel playfully and distinctly ‘human.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Biden’s Big Vision Collides With His Small Majorities
description: The president’s push for transformative policies is running into the realities of governing with no votes to spare.
content: WASHINGTON — When President Biden took office, he made the case that a pandemic that had touched off a national crisis could foster a new consensus in Washington, softening partisan divisions and allowing for the kind of transformational change that would meet a devastating and dangerous moment for the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero
title: In Arizona, Drought Ignites Tensions and Threatens Traditions Among the Hopi
description: The tribe has survived for more than a thousand years in the arid mesas. The megadrought gripping the Southwest is testing that resilience.
content: MOENKOPI, Ariz. — On the bone-dry plateau where the Hopi people have lived for well over a thousand years, Robinson Honani pulled his truck to the side of a dirt road and pointed to a carcass.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salman Masood
title: Pakistan in Talks With Taliban Militants, Even as Attacks Ramp Up
description: Prime Minister Imran Khan said his government was in preliminary negotiations with factions of the Pakistani Taliban, but details remained murky.
content: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan is holding talks with factions of the Pakistani Taliban, a banned militant group responsible for some of the country’s worst terrorist attacks, and would forgive members who lay down their weapons, Prime Minister Imran Khan said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Empty Desks at the State Department, Courtesy of Ted Cruz
description: Dozens of nominations have been held up by a fight between the Texas senator and the Biden administration over a Russian gas pipeline project.
content: WASHINGTON — The arrival of a new U.S. ambassador to Mexico is usually a routine event. But for the Biden administration, it was a notable victory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: Nearly 40 Million People Are Still Enslaved Worldwide
description: In India, rock quarry miners fought landowners who had held their families in bondage for generations.
content: Nearly 40 million of people around the world are enslaved today, and the largest number live in India. There, in the northern state of Uttar Pradesh, rock quarry miners fought landowners who had held their families in bondage for generations. They liberated themselves in July 2000 and began running their own quarries. It was this model of self-emancipation that motivated Laura T. Murphy to study contemporary forms of slavery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Gutierrez
title: Duterte Says He Will Retire Rather Than Seek the Vice Presidency
description: The Philippine president, whose term ends next year, had been expected to seek the No. 2 office, but said he would not do so “in obedience to the will of the people.”
content: MANILA — President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines said on Saturday that he would retire rather than pursue the vice presidency next year, a surprise reversal of a plan meant to keep him in government after his presidential term ends.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Tesla Reports Record Quarterly Deliveries Amid Chip Scarcity
description: The electric-car maker has weathered the global shortage of semiconductors better than more established rivals.
content: Even as more established automakers reported slowing sales because of supply constraints, Tesla said Saturday that it achieved a healthy increase in worldwide deliveries of its electric cars in the third quarter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Precious Fondren
title: Statues Reflecting on Racial Injustice Go Up in Union Square
description: Sculptures of George Floyd, Breonna Taylor and John Lewis are on display in a Manhattan park known as a site of protests. “These monuments have meaning,” Mr. Floyd’s brother said.
content: In Union Square on Friday night, Terrence Floyd — a brother of George Floyd, whose murder in May 2020 by a police officer prompted confrontations over police brutality and racial injustice — spoke softly into a microphone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: American, Alaska Airlines and JetBlue add vaccine mandates for workers.
description: American said the move was necessary in light of President Biden’s move to require vaccinations against the coronavirus for employees of government contractors.
content: American Airlines told employees on Friday that it would require all U.S.-based employees and some international crew members to be vaccinated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Cheer Up, Liberals. You Have the America You Wanted.
description: America in 2021 is the country that liberals in the Bush era pined for.
content: There is a certain pall over American liberalism as the negotiations over the infrastructure and reconciliation bills drag on — a feeling that even if a deal is negotiated (as I assume one will be), it will represent a last gasp for progressive policymaking, a final desperate advance before the American system’s rightward tilt restores Republican power or else a constitutional crisis hits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Storyful
title: Demonstrators March for Abortion Rights
description: Thousands participated across the United States in the fifth annual Women’s March, specifically focused on abortion rights.
content: Thousands participated across the United States in the fifth annual Women’s March, specifically focused on abortion rights.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Oct. 2, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Oct. 2, 2021.
content: A television review of “The Problem With Jon Stewart” rendered incorrectly a remark Stewart made during a 2004 appearance on “Crossfire.” He said, “The show that leads into me is puppets making crank phone calls,” not “The show that leads into me is puppets making prank phone calls.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Cancel Culture: Are We Overreacting?
description: Readers mostly disagree with a column by Michelle Goldberg that suggests that we are, and she responds to their critiques.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
